review.title: Concept Generation in Language Evolution
review.abstract: This thesis investigates the generation of new concepts from combinations of existing concepts as a language evolves. We give a method for combining concepts, and will be investigating the utility of composite concepts in language evolution and thence the utility of concept generation.

metadata.title: Concept Generation in Language Evolution

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: In order to create artificial languages for implementation in AI systems, we need to model this capability. Standardized approaches to combining concepts, such as fuzzy set theory, have proved insufficient [Osherson and Smith, 1981]. Composite labels often have "emerging attributes" [Hampton, 1987] that cannot be explained by splitting the label into its constituent parts. We argue that in this case, a new concept is generated. This project aims to determine the conditions for such concept generation using multi-agent models of language development.

sections.heading: 1.1 Thesis Outline
sections.text: The project is divided into three parts. Firstly, we have developed a model of concept combination within the semantic framework of the label, as explained in [Lawry and Tang, 2009], which is inspired and reflects the results of [Hampton, 1987], in which membership in a network concept can be presented as a weighted sum of memberships in individual concepts. Secondly, we need to show that compositionality can develop within a population of interacting agents. Preparatory work in this area will examine the ability of a population of agents to merge into a common number of dimensional weights. Thirdly, we will investigate the generation of new unit concepts from existing network concepts based on the multi-agent model.

sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: This work is based on the framework of label semantics [Lawry, 2004; Lawry and Tang, 2009], together with the prototype theory [Rosch, 1975], where belonging to a concept is based on proximity to a prototype and conceptual spaces [Ga � rdenfors, 2004]. The latter considers concepts as regions of a space consisting of quality dimensions and equipped with distance measurement, e.g. the RGB color space. Label semantics suggests that agents use a series of labels LA = {L1,..., Ln} to describe a conceptual space equipped with distance measurement d (x, y). Labels Li are associated with prototypes Pi ст and uncertain thresholds εi, which are drawn from probability distributions εi. The threshold εi captures the notion that an element x-i is sufficiently close to Pi (εix) to be called Li.

sections.heading: 3 A New Model of Concept Composition
sections.text: Experiments in [Hampton, 1987] suggest that the human conceptual combination (coarse) can be modeled as a weighted sum of attributes such as "has feathers," "speaks" (for the concept of "bird") These attributes differ from quality dimensions in conceptual spaces: they tend to be binary, complex and multidimensional. sections.heading: 5 Further Work
sections.text: We are currently working on analytical results to predict the value of λ to which the active ingredients converge. In certain circumstances, such as in the case of w = 1 or with a modified update model, analytical results are possible. We will expand this work to investigate the benefits of using conjunctival claims within these simulations, and the work in the third year will focus on investigating how new concepts might emerge from the combination of existing concepts. We will build on the language development model currently under development.

2 Background This work is based on the label semantics framework [Lawry, 2004; Lawry and Tang, 2009], together with prototype theory [Rosch, 1975], where membership in a concept is based on proximity to a prototype, and conceptual spaces [Gärdenfors, 2004].
Experiments in [Hampton, 1987] propose that human concept combination can (roughly) be modelled as a weighted sum of attributes such as ‘has feathers’, ‘talks’ (for the concept ‘Bird’).

We have therefore shown that combining labels in a weighted binary space leads naturally to the creation of composite and compound concepts as weighted sums of individual labels, reflecting results in [Hampton, 1987].
